item.title: [TUT][CODE]on varibles And input
item.dc:creator: @Cheese_Police c|p
item.description:
@Cheese_Police wrote:

1337h4x:

Back when I was learning java there were no scanners, and you had to do like a 10 line setup just to get input…

BufferedReader in = new BufferedReader(new InputStreamReader(System.in)); int i; String line; while ((line = in.readLine()) != null) { if (line.matches("\\d+)) { i = Integer.parseInt(line); break; } }

lel

item.title: [TUT][CODE]on varibles And input
item.dc:creator: @BobDole81 BobDole81
item.description:
@BobDole81 wrote:

1337h4x:

Back when I was learning java there were no scanners, and you had to do like a 10 line setup just to get input…

10 lines? Please…BufferedReader only used 1 line: new BufferedReader(new InputStreamReader(System.in))

The main advantages with Scanner is that it shortens this and you don’t have to bother casting input all the time.

Read full topic

item.title: [TUT][CODE]on varibles And input
item.dc:creator: @BobDole81 BobDole81
item.description:
@BobDole81 wrote:

getNextFloat() doesn’t exist But nextFloat() also doesn’t parse the entire line…it splits the lines base on a certain set of tokens and will parse each individually.

So if you inputted a line: “12.33 992”
You could call nextFloat() and nextInt() to obtain those values, whereas nextLine() would return that entire line.

Read full topic

item.title: [TUT][CODE]on varibles And input
item.dc:creator: @1337h4x 1337h4x
item.description:
@1337h4x wrote:

like this:

[code]import java.util.*;

public class ImBord
{
public static void main(String[] args)
{
int var1 = 0;
int var2 = 0;
int var3 = 0;

	Scanner input = new Scanner(System.in);

	System.out.println("ok so this is to show you that if you declere a varible as 0 then input \na number to it. it will add it to it. here is a simple program to show that");
	System.out.println("here thay are  " + var1 + "  " + var2 + "  " + var3 +".");
	System.out.println("enter the varibles");

	System.out.print("var1 : ");
	var1 = input.nextInt();

	System.out.print("var2 : ");
	var2 = input.nextInt();

	System.out.print("var3 : ");
	var3 = input.nextInt();

	System.out.println("now thay are  " + var1 + "  " + var2 + "  " + var3 +".");
}

}[/code]

Read full topic

item.title: [TUT][CODE]on varibles And input
item.dc:creator: @N00b1 N00b1
item.description:
@N00b1 wrote:

Difficultly 2

What you need: a simple txt editor or Txt-pad --recommended

Knowledge: simple copping and understanding of the very basics of java.

What you need to do…
Rite here I go to start off with open up Txt-pad and set out your bacic backbone

public class ImBord {
	public static void main(String[] args){
}}

ok now that we’ve got that we need to import a directory called java.utill
so rite at the top of our page add this

import java.util.*;

so it will than look like this

import java.util.*;
public class ImBord{
	public static void main(String[] args){

now you have to declare your variables what are variables… well there things that the input of you can change they are a few of them but we will just look at the ones to do with numbers witch are
int
float
there may be a few more but there the ones that we will be working with for this tut
we may also touch up on the one to do with text witch is
String
String MUST have a caps “S” the java compiler is very strict on this it will NOT compile with out this caps S
So here is what you must put in we will have 2 varibles one float and one int and one String. Set it out like this

	int var1 =
	float var2 =

Ok so we have declared that they are an int a float and a and we have gave them names var1, var2 now to set values to them

	int var1 = 0;
	float var2 = 0;

Ok now we have set them to that so we can input things over them and it will not change the values that we input later because there 0
Now we must say that we want a new scanner witch will deal with all of our inputs

		Scanner input = new Scanner(System.in);

So add that in under our variables.
Now add this in under that

		System.out.println("please input a number");

Don’t forget that System need a caps “S” as well System means that your telling the System to do something out means its an out put and print means that it needs to print something out into the System…
Println is better because it automatically puts a new line after the end of the txt.
Now to add this in underneath that

		var1 = input.nextInt();

so your saying that var1 = the input of the next int that the user inputs to the computer
now onto your next line

		System.out.print("please input another number");
		var2 = input.nextfloat();

Ok that is the same as the top line just change a few bits I think you can work that out if u cant quit! Lol
Now to close the inputs

[code]
input.close();
[/code
Now to display all the info

		System.out.println("heres your info var1 = " + var1 + " var2 = " + var2 + "");

No just to close it all

}}

and compile if you are using Txt-pad then use CTRL + 1

then run CTRL + 2

then its done I hope you have enjoyed

this is it all put together

import java.util.*;

public class tut1
{
	
	public static void main(String[] args)
	{
		
		int var1 = 0;
		
		float var2 = 0;
		
		
		Scanner input = new Scanner(System.in);
		
		System.out.println("please input a number");
		var1 = input.nextInt();
		
		System.out.println("please imput another number");
		var2 = input.nextFloat();
		
		input.close();
		
		System.out.println("heres your info var1 = " + var1 + " var2 = " + var2 + "");
		}
	}

and this is just one I made that mite let you understand it better

[code]
import java.util.*;

public class ImBord
{

public static void main(String[] args)
{
	
	int var1 = 0;
	int var2 = 0;
	int var3 = 0;
	
	Scanner input = new Scanner(System.in);
	
	System.out.println("ok so this is to show you that if you declere a varible as 0 then input \na number to it. it will add it to it. here is a simple program to show that");
	System.out.println("here thay are  " + var1 + "  " + var2 + "  " + var3 +".");
	
	System.out.println("enter the varibles");
	System.out.print("var1 : ");
	var1 = input.nextInt();
	
	System.out.print("var2 : ");
	var2 = input.nextInt();
	
	System.out.print("var3 : ");
	var3 = input.nextInt();
	
	System.out.println("now thay are  " + var1 + "  " + var2 + "  " + var3 +".");
}

}
[/code]

all creds to me n00b1[/code]
